request_pathways.name: Authorization for Release of Protected Health Information
Mail completed form to Medical Records department

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients use a generic 'Authorization for Release of Protected Health Information' form designed for third-party release, listing themselves as recipient to request their own records.

red_flags: Full SSN collection on a form designed to be mailed, creating identity theft risk
Blanket disclosure of substance abuse, psychiatric, and communicable disease records without separate consent, potentially conflicting with 42 CFR Part 2
bright_spots: Full Spanish-language translation with interpreter services phone number
Granular record-type checklist with ~25 categories giving patients meaningful control
Copies and faxes explicitly accepted as valid as originals
Proactive adoption of 2024 HIPAA reproductive health attestation form

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available with minimal effort — a basic web search immediately surfaces the Medical Records page, which links directly to all forms with no barriers.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: The PDF has a text layer but zero fillable fields (print-and-handwrite required); fax submission is acknowledged as valid per Condition 6 though no fax number is provided; MyChart offers a digital alternative but the primary form is paper-first.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized two-page layout with clear three-section structure, granular record-type checklist, and appropriate length; minor issues with moderately formal language in authorization conditions.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the form but it was not designed for self-access — the sender/recipient framing requires patients to figure out they should list themselves as recipient, with no mention of HIPAA Right of Access.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: SSN collection goes beyond legal requirements for patient access; blanket substance abuse/psychiatric disclosure may conflict with 42 CFR Part 2; fee amounts undisclosed; offset by no notarization requirement and clear revocation rights.

overall.summary: Lexington Medical Center offers easy-to-find, bilingual forms with clear layout, but the generic third-party authorization framework, non-fillable PDF, and compliance concerns with SSN collection and blanket sensitive-records disclosure hold it back from a higher grade.
